title: Diatonic Chords
description: Learn all 7 chords built from the C major scale — the foundation of harmonic analysis.

steps.title: Chords from the Scale
steps.description:
Every major scale produces 7 chords when you stack 3rds from each note. In C major:

• I = C (major)
• ii = Dm (minor)
• iii = Em (minor)
• IV = F (major)
• V = G (major)
• vi = Am (minor)
• vii° = Bdim (diminished)

Uppercase = major, lowercase = minor. This pattern is the same in every major key!

steps.title: I — C Major
steps.description: The tonic chord. This is 'home' — the most stable, resolved-sounding chord.

steps.title: ii — D Minor
steps.description: The supertonic. Often leads to the V chord. Very common in pop progressions.

steps.title: iii — E Minor
steps.description: The mediant. Can substitute for the I chord and adds a subtle sadness.

steps.title: IV — F Major
steps.description: The subdominant. Feels like moving away from home. One of the three primary chords.

steps.title: V — G Major
steps.description: The dominant. Creates the strongest pull back to the I chord. Essential for cadences.

steps.title: vi — A Minor
steps.description: The submediant. The relative minor chord. Used heavily in pop (I-V-vi-IV).

steps.title: vii° — B Diminished
steps.description: The leading tone chord. Tense and rare, but it leads strongly to C major.

steps.title: Diatonic Quiz
steps.description: In a major key, which chords are minor?
